name: 1h-indole-3-propanoic acid
Reason: The basic unit of the target compound includes an indole core which itself is structurally similar to benzene and would therefore have a melting point comparable to benzene's, which is around 5.5°C. However, the indole core is more rigid and planar due to the extra nitrogen-containing five-membered ring, which should increase the melting point significantly. The presence of the propanoic acid side chain introduces additional factors: (1) The carboxylic acid group is capable of strong hydrogen bonding, which generally increases the melting point notably. (2) The extra carbon atoms in the propyl group increase the molecular weight and provide a small hydrophobic effect. Overall, the combined hydrogen bonding of the carboxylic acid group and the increased rigidity of the indole core should have the largest effect on increasing the melting point, with a smaller contribution from the propyl group. Estimations: Indole core: +110°C (due to planar rigidity and aromaticity), Carboxylic acid group: +60°C (due to hydrogen bonding capability), Propyl group: +10°C (due to an increase in molecular weight and hydrophobic interactions).

name: 1h-indole-3-propanoic acid
Reason: The basic unit of the target compound is indole, which is already more rigid and has a higher melting point than benzene due to the presence of the nitrogen atom and the fused ring system, contributing to stronger intermolecular forces. The melting point of indole is known to be around 52°C. Adding the propanoic acid side chain introduces two significant effects: (1) the carboxylic acid group forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, significantly increasing the melting point. (2) The propyl group adds some molecular weight and van der Waals forces, slightly increasing the melting point. However, since the carboxylic acid's effect is far stronger due to hydrogen bonding, it gets a more considerable addition in the estimation. Estimations: indole core with additional rigidity and nitrogen: +40°C, carboxylic acid group: +45°C (due to the strong hydrogen bonding), propyl group: +5°C (minor contribution from increased molecular weight and hydrophobic effect).
